Description: Oblong scaraboid in glazed composition, probably mould-made; back in the shape of a couchant lion; underside bearing hieroglyphic signs arranged vertically with owl, sun-disc above back and line (debased hieroglyph to write n-water sign?); hard yellow glaze.
Curator's comments: Scaraboid not yet located, published by Petrie (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, no. 99). Lion scaraboids belong to a common series produced at Naukratis (on the ‘Scarab Factory’ productions, see Webb forthcoming). Moulds to produce lion scaraboids were discovered in Naukratis: BM 1896,0610.16 and BM 1896,0610.17. Numerous couchant lion scaraboids were discovered in Naukratis (see for example the ones illustrated in Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, nos. 50, 64, 69, 80, 92, 99, 104). The owl sign is often associated on Naukratite scarabs and scaraboids with solar symbols (see example of an owl between an obelisk and sun-disc in Gorton 1996, 103, no. 84) or other sacred signs (Maat feather, ankh sign: Gardner 1888, pl. XVIII, 42; Gorton 1996, 104). This scaraboid belongs to a type widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 93-107, type XXVIII B, see especially B99 for this piece). Though the hieroglyphic signs could have just some magical value, it is possible that this is a cryptographic reading for the name of Amun (on the cryptic writing of the name of Amun: Drioton 1957). The lion shape of the scaraboid itself can be associated with solar deties. Lions were used to write the name of Ra during the Late Period, as the lion is a phonetic equivalent Rw (De Wit 1951, 138ff).
